title: Understanding Fractions: Unit Fractions and Building Up
description: Complete coverage of CCSS 3.NF.A.1: Understand unit fractions 1/b as 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts, and understand fractions a/b as 'a' parts of size 1/b. Uses concrete examples (chocolate bars, pizza, paper strips) to build conceptual understanding.
subject: fractions

standards.description: Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; understand a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b.

objectives: Understand that a unit fraction 1/b represents 1 part when a whole is divided into b EQUAL parts
Recognize that the denominator (bottom number) tells how many equal parts the whole is divided into
Understand that a fraction a/b represents 'a' parts, each of size 1/b
Identify and create examples of both unit fractions (1/2, 1/3, 1/4) and non-unit fractions (2/3, 3/4)
Recognize and correct common misconceptions about equal partitioning and fraction size

milestones.title: Understanding Unit Fractions (1/b)
milestones.description: Student understands that 1/b means 1 part when a whole is divided into b equal parts
milestones.prompt: Let's start with a chocolate bar. If we break it into 2 equal pieces, what do we call each piece? What if we broke it into 3 equal pieces? Or 4?
expectedConcepts: When we divide into b equal parts, each part is 1/b
The bottom number (denominator) tells how many equal parts

milestones.title: Equal Partitioning Requirement
milestones.description: Student can explain why equal partitioning is essential and identify when partitioning is unequal
milestones.prompt: What if I cut the chocolate bar but one piece is bigger than the other? Can we still call them halves? Why or why not?
expectedConcepts: Unequal pieces cannot be called fractions

milestones.title: Building Non-Unit Fractions (a/b)
milestones.description: Student understands that a/b means 'a' parts, each of size 1/b
milestones.prompt: If one piece is 1/3 of a pizza, what would two pieces be? What about three pieces out of four?
expectedConcepts: The top number (numerator) tells how many parts we have
a/b is built from unit fractions: a Ã— (1/b)

milestones.title: Connecting Notation to Meaning
milestones.description: Student can explain what the numerator and denominator represent in any fraction a/b
milestones.prompt: In the fraction 3/4, what does the 4 tell us? What does the 3 tell us?
expectedConcepts: Denominator = how many equal parts the whole is divided into
Numerator = how many of those parts we're talking about
Understanding the structure of fraction notation

milestones.title: Apply to Multiple Contexts
milestones.description: Student can identify and create fractions in various real-world scenarios
milestones.prompt: Show me 2/3 of a pizza. Show me 3/4 of a rectangle. Can you give me other examples?
expectedConcepts: Can represent fractions with different shapes

hints: Think about sharing fairly - all pieces must be the exact same size
The bottom number tells you how many equal parts to make
The top number tells you how many of those parts you're taking
Start with unit fractions (1/2, 1/3, 1/4) then build up to 2/3, 3/4
Use concrete objects: chocolate bars, pizza slices, paper strips

commonMisconceptions.description: Thinking any division creates fractions, even if parts are unequal
evidence: Student says 'I divided it into 3 pieces so each is 1/3' without checking if pieces are equal
Student accepts unequal pieces as valid fractions
commonMisconceptions.correction: A fraction requires EQUAL partitioning. If parts aren't the same size, we can't use fraction notation. Ask: 'Are all the pieces exactly the same size?'

commonMisconceptions.description: Confusing what numerator and denominator represent
evidence: Student thinks 3/4 means 'divide into 3 parts, take 4'
Student can't explain what the numbers mean
commonMisconceptions.correction: Bottom number (denominator) = how many equal parts we divide the whole into. Top number (numerator) = how many of those parts we're talking about. In 3/4: divide into 4 equal parts, take 3 of them.

evidence: Student says '1/8 is more than 1/2 because 8 is bigger than 2'
commonMisconceptions.correction: The denominator tells how many pieces the whole is cut into. More pieces means SMALLER pieces. 1/8 is smaller than 1/2 because when you cut something into 8 pieces, each piece is smaller than when you cut it into only 2 pieces.

commonMisconceptions.description: Not understanding that you can have multiple parts (non-unit fractions)
evidence: Student thinks you can only have 'one third', not 'two thirds'
commonMisconceptions.correction: After understanding 1/b (unit fractions), we can have multiple parts: 2/3 means we have 2 pieces, each of size 1/3. It's like having two 1/3 portions.

commonMisconceptions.description: Treating fractions as two separate whole numbers instead of one quantity
evidence: Student treats 3/4 as '3 and 4' instead of one number
Student tries to add numerators and denominators separately
commonMisconceptions.correction: A fraction is ONE number that represents a quantity. 3/4 is one amount, not two separate numbers. It means 3 parts, each of size 1/4.
